content.description: Climb the wide crack in the middle of the wall.  The crux is passing the small overhang close to the top.
content.location: Obvious crack in the middle of the wall

content.description:
One of the easier climbs at warming wall.   It acts as a good introduction to the climbing here.

Delicately climb up to the 1st bolt, and on through steeper climbing to the 2nd (crux).  Continue on up passing several interesting sections, but never far from a rest.
content.location:
Located just left of

Warming Wall Crack

content.description: Small edges lead to difficult layback moves and pockets which end at a slab, then negotiate a bulge to the anchors.
content.location: Route just left of "Jam It"

content.description:
This is one of the better routes at Warming Wall.  It starts right of Heat Vampire.

Climb up to the first bolt, and continue over the small overlap to clip the 2nd bolt.  Getting to and passing the 2nd bolt is the crux and provides some fine moves.    The difficulties soon ease as a large pocket and a finger ledge are reached and the 3rd bolt clipped.  With little more effort continue on up to the top.

The first 3 bolts provide some fine sustained climbing at the grade.
content.location: Climbs the prow of rock right of Heat Vampire.

content.description:
The difficulties are soon upon you as you climb passed the 1st bolt and onto the 2nd.   Passing the bulge and getting to the 3rd bolt is the crux.

The climbing above while not as difficult is good, with a nice exposed finished (albeit protected with a bolt).
content.location:
This is the 2nd climb left of the Warming Wall Crack, and just right of

One Eyed Jack

.

content.description:
This climb starts with a steep section straight of the ground.   Make good moves up and passed the 2nd bolt.  By the 3rd bolt the crux is done.

Steep enjoyable climbing on jugs takes you over the overhang and up to the anchors.
content.location: Located towards the left side of the cliff.

climbs.name: The Moroccan wizard
climbs.fa: Alon Peretz (let me know if you climbed before)

content.description:
Starts with a layback to a slab finger lock that takes good protection, you go to the right and then traverse to the left of the anchor. Along the way there are 4 good pockets to place gear. In the last few traverse moves you can either run out or place a BD number 2 in the pocket next to the small bush .

You should take from 0.3-3

null
content.protection:
You should take from 0.3-3

Bolted anchor
content.location: Starts to the right of Kyoto protocol and ends at the anchor of El Ni√±o

climbs.name: Kyoto Protocol
climbs.fa: Euan Cameron and Julie Wright, 9th May 2009

content.description:
Start below a steep right facing corner.   Climb up the corner passing two bolts until the capping overhang, and the 3rd bolt is reached.   Pass the overhang on the left and move back right to the 4th bolt.

Move over easier ground to the 5th bolt, taking care of some questionable rock.

From the 5th bolt step right and climb through the overhang on good holds to reach the anchors up on the right.
content.location:
Located on the left side of the wall between

El Nino

and

Nuclear Winter

.

content.description:
Jam it starts where the graffiti says it should.   The climb comes at you fast with some hard face moves, which soon ease.

Getting to the 2nd bolt is the crux sequence.  less sustained climbing follows up to the anchors.
content.protection: Bolts, triple shut anchor (shared with Heat Vampire)
content.location: Located at the left side of the cliff, the climb is easily found by following the graffiti.

content.description:
This route climbs the steeping slab to a short wall passing the 4th bolt.

Some of the holds are a bit crunchy but with more traffic it'll clean up nicely.
content.location: Right side of the main wall

content.description:
This climb has one hard move, the rest is fun climbing on fairly easy terrain.

Nice face climbing up to the 3rd bolt brings you to the crux move around a small bulge.   Quickly pass this and continue on up.
content.location: The last bolted route before the large chimney on the right of the main face.

content.description: Overhanging wall with small edges to a 2 finger pocket, then powerful moves over the bulge(crux), easier climbing leads to a final bulge and the anchors.
content.location: Route just left of Tittytwister

content.description:
This route lies just to the right of

Jam It

(5.11b). Although the climbing isn't as hard as Jam It, it is more sustained.

After a steep start on large holds the climb progresses upwards to a fingery finish.
content.protection: 7 bolts, triple shut anchor (shared with Jam It)
content.location:
Start just right of

Jam It

, below an overhang.

content.description:
Climb the strenuous bulge through to the 3rd bolt.

Beware, the flake at which forms part of the crux sequence is defiantly not to be trusted.
content.location: Second bolted line right of the chimney on the right of the main face.

content.description: Climb the easy lower-angled face that is just right of the obvious chimney to the right of Warming Wall Crack. At the top of the pillar, step around right and up to the large tree.
content.location: Start at a lower-angled face that is just right of the obvious chimney to the right of Warming Wall Crack.

content.description: The climb starts OK, but soon deteriorates into a sequence of mantles on big ledges.   Its a pity because the start is kinda fun.
content.location: Right of Faulty Break

content.description:
Start by climbing the steep feature wall up to the first bolt.  Continue on up to the 3rd bolt where a brief rest allows you to eye up the crux.

Moving passed the 3rd bolt is the crux - the sequence isn't that obvious, but progress is rewarded with a killer jug and the 4th bolt.

Finish up the featured slab to the anchors.
content.location: Leftmost route on the main wall

climbs.name: Faulty Break
climbs.fa: Malcolm Jolly, Meri Jolley, Gregg Davis, Cynthia Dayhoff, 1989

content.description:
The first half of the climb is really good, with some nice fingery climbing that requires good technique.

The second half doesn't live up to the first, but it isn't all bad.
content.location: Located just left of the "Brake" graffiti

climbs.name: El Nino
climbs.fa: Malcolm Jolly, Meri Jolley, Vivian Farsworth, 1989

content.description:
The climb is short, and the holds appear big.   Don't be fooled.

The first half of the climb is steep, but the holds really are good.   The second half provides the crux with a tricky sequence getting up to and passed the last bolt.
content.location: Located at the left hand end of the Warming Wall, on an overhanging prow.

content.description:
This squeezes a nice climb into this area of the face, which although easier than

Ghetto Blaster

, the climbing is better and more sustained for its grade.
content.location:
Located between

Ghetto Blaster

and

Hot Flash

content.description:
This is one of the better 10s at Warming Wall.

Start by climbing a steep wall.   This is the first crux.   Continue on up with a large mantelshelf.

Before the anchors are reached you need to keep some finger strength for the final bulge.   This often proves the trickiest section.

Make sure you use your feet, and don't hang around on the small crimps.
content.location: This is the first bolted line right of Warming Wall Crack

content.description: Climb past a small bulge with a long reach, and continue up the easy angled face above.
content.location: Right most route

content.description:
This climbs the overhanging left hand edge of the rightmost part of the cliff.

Climb steeply up past two bolts.   Now you must commit and find the crux sequence.   Clip the 3rd bolt and continue with up to the top with little more effort.
content.location: First bolted line (Black hangers) right of the chimney on the right of the main face.

content.description: A couple of long reaches will see you past the crux.   Uneventful climbing brings you to the second crux passing the last bolt.
content.location: Situated between Greenhouse Effect and Unknown 3
